PAGE.TITLE: Limit of a function
PAGE.DESCRIPTION:
In mathematics a limit of a function is the value the function approaches as the input approaches some value. Limits are essential to calculus and are used to define continuity, derivatives and integrals. In formulas, a limit is usually written as:
$$
\lim_{n \rightarrow c} f(n) = L
$$
which is read as "in the limit as $n$ approaches $c$ the function $f(n)$ equals $L$."
Limits often appear when you have functions that are quotients:
$$
f(x) = \frac{g(x)}{h(x)}
$$
the reason being that if there can be values of $x$ for which the function in the numerator, $g(x)$, and the function in the denominator, $h(x)$, both equal either $0$ or $\infty$. The values of $\frac{0}{0}$ and $\frac{\infty}{\infty}$ are both undefined.

UL.LI: You should be able to explain what we mean by a limit and why limits are important in mathematics.
You should be able to explain when we need to find the value of a function by solving a limit. In other words, you should be able to recognise the input values at which the function is undefined.
You should be able to find the values of limits of quotients by manipulating the expression into a more pliant form using algebraic arguments.
